repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes #5393

> Note: documentation needs to be updated too

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9079,7 +9079,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
                                 construct (replaced by its compile time value)
     """
 
-    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads']
+    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads', 'if_']

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    if_ = None
```

I think I prefer `if_` anyway
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9090,6 +9090,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
 
     num_threads = None
     chunksize = None
+    _if = None

@@ -9090,6 +9090,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
 
     num_threads = None
     chunksize = None
+    _if = None

comment_data.body:
This seems a useless comment. Why add an additional comment line to code that does exactly what the comment says in just two clear lines?
```suggestion
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9793,9 +9805,17 @@ def generate_execution_code(self, code):
         self.declare_closure_privates(code)
         self.setup_parallel_control_flow_block(code)
 
+        if self.if_ is not None:
+            self.if_.generate_evaluation_code(code)
+
         code.putln("#ifdef _OPENMP")
         code.put("#pragma omp parallel ")
 
+        # Add if statement, if present

comment_data.body:
It's bad enough to make users write option names with underscores at end (or start), but we shouldn't do this internally, and there is no reason to use the same name for both the user visible option and the internal representation. We can name the internal variables/attributes `threading_condition`, for example. Trailing underscores disrupt the reading and make readers think, entirely unnecessarily.

We can also name the user option `only_if`. `parallel(only_if=condition)` reads even a bit better to me than a blank `if`, I think, let alone a distracting `if_`. `use_threads_if=condition` seems even more descriptive and does not even need a reference to the OMP spec.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9079,7 +9079,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
                                 construct (replaced by its compile time value)
     """
 
-    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads']
+    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads', 'if_']

comment_data.body:
The spacing looks wrong here.
```suggestion
            code.put("if(%s) " % self.if_.result())
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9793,9 +9805,17 @@ def generate_execution_code(self, code):
         self.declare_closure_privates(code)
         self.setup_parallel_control_flow_block(code)
 
+        if self.if_ is not None:
+            self.if_.generate_evaluation_code(code)
+
         code.putln("#ifdef _OPENMP")
         code.put("#pragma omp parallel ")
 
+        # Add if statement, if present
+        if self.if_ is not None:
+            code.put(" if(%s)" % self.if_.result())

comment_data.body:
This seems a useless (and misleading) comment. There is only one such statement, and it is _obviously_ added to the code here.
```suggestion
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -10099,6 +10122,11 @@ def generate_loop(self, code, fmt_dict):
             reduction_codepoint = self.parent.privatization_insertion_point
         else:
             code.put("#pragma omp parallel")
+
+            # Add if-statements to code

comment_data.body: As I have mentioned, `if_` is not final version. I wanted to have something just to finish implementation. I am open to any suggestion. I like `use_threads_if` more, so I will use it instead of `if_`. If there will be consensus on other name I am fine to change it again.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9079,7 +9079,7 @@ class ParallelStatNode(StatNode, ParallelNode):
                                 construct (replaced by its compile time value)
     """
 
-    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads']
+    child_attrs = ['body', 'num_threads', 'if_']
